metadata.synopsis: A wandering cowboy (Herbert Jeffries) helps the daughter (Connie Harris) of a former outlaw find the gold her father stole 20 years earlier and return it to its owners.

reviews: [Harlem On The Prairie] is from the technical standpoint, a considerable improvement on past race-produced pictures.
The photography and settings are above the average and the team of Miller and Mantan get the honors for acting.

In it are combined the necessary elements of melodrama, romance, comedy, suspense, action and surprise. Well photographed scenic backgrounds are an asset and... solo, chorus and instrumental music add to the entertainment.

There's a singing cowboy hero, a charming heroine, a melodious quartet, two amusing comedians, but best of all I liked the villain. I guess because he reminded me of Akim Tamiroff. If you like Westerns, this one will be an innovation.

Herbert Jeffries, the hard riding gun throwing hero, has a fine voice which he uses to advantage. There is a good quartet that aids him, and the comedy team of Miller and Mantan provides some amusing scenes.
Best parts of the picture are the tunes, Harlem on the Prairie and Romance in the Rain.
The acting and technical standards of the film are poor.
The title song and "Romance in the Rain" are the outstanders, in which Herb Jeffries, the singing cowboy hero, distinguishes himself vocally as well as manfully.
